thread.title: JP Energy Partners: Top Midstream MLP Loser on September 25 - Yahoo Finance
thread.title_full: JP Energy Partners: Top Midstream MLP Loser on September 25 - Yahoo Finance

author: Kurt Gallon
title: JP Energy Partners: Top Midstream MLP Loser on September 25 - Yahoo Finance
text:
Midstream and Upstream MLP Gainers and Losers on September 25 
( Continued from Prior Part )
Top losers In the last part, we saw the top five midstream MLP gainers on Friday, September 25. In this part, we’ll discuss the top five midstream MLP losers on the same day.

JP Energy Partners JP Energy Partners (JPEP) was the top loser among midstream MLPs at the end of trading on Friday, September 25. JP Energy Partners fell 8.71% yesterday. It has lost 46.03% of its equity value since the beginning of this year. The partnership mainly provides crude oil, refined products, and NGL (natural gas liquid) gathering, transportation, and storage services.
Valero Energy Partners Valero Energy Partners (VLP) is next on our list of the top five midstream MLP losers on September 25. Despite a recent asset drop-down announcement, Valero Energy Partners fell 3.63% on Friday. In a press release published on September 23, Valero Energy Partners announced that it would acquire the Corpus Christi Terminal Services Business from a subsidiary of Valero Energy (VLO) for a total consideration of $465 million. Valero Energy holds Valero Energy Partners’ GP (general partner).
According to the company’s press release, “The Partnership plans to enter into a 10-year terminaling agreement with a subsidiary of Valero. The business to be acquired is expected to contribute approximately $50 million of EBITDA in its first full year of operation.”
The deal is expected to be financed with $395 million in borrowings and “issuance of additional common units and general partners units to Valero subsidiaries valued collectively at approximately $70 million. ”
Other losers Western Refining Logistics (WNRL), DCP Midstream Partners (DPM), and NuStar Energy (NS) were among the top five midstream MLP losers on Friday, September 25. They lost 3.31%, 2.12%, and 2.06% in the last trading session, respectively. These three stocks have returned -29.08%, -46.07%, and -19.22% YTD (year-to-date), respectively.
The Alerian MLP ETF (AMLP) and the Global X MLP & Energy Infrastructure ETF (MLPX) have returned -25.86% and -23.45% YTD. DCP Midstream Partners accounts for 2.19% of AMLP. For context, the upstream energy company heavy SPDR S&P Oil & Gas Exploration & Production ETF (XOP) has returned -30.07% YTD.
Continue to Next Part
